<div class="c6 " style="margin-bottom:7px">
<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
TECH
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/01/07/sonos-sues-google-bully-allegedly?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Sonos Sues Google for Being a Bully
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="A gavel that's made out of a Google speaker " style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiIxNTc4NDM0NDg2LmpwZyIsImJ1Y2tldCI6Im1vcm5pbmdicmV3LW9zbG8iLCJlZGl0cyI6eyJyZXNpemUiOnsid2lkdGgiOjEwMDAsImhlaWdodCI6bnVsbH19fQ==">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Francis Scialabba</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Listening to music on a Sonos speaker is like getting a personal serenade from Nick Jonas. But after going on tour with Big Tech, the high-end speaker company wants out: Yesterday, Sonos <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/07/technology/sonos-sues-google.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">sued</a> Google for allegedly infringing on five of its patents, the NYT reports. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">In a <a href="https://www.scribd.com/document/442039322/Sonos-ITC-Complaint-against-Google?campaign=SkimbitLtd&ad_group=66960X1514734Xe44b477fa03a05e24af3574ac830e523&keyword=660149026&source=hp_affiliate&medium=affiliate&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">separate case</a>, it's also requesting a ban on the sale of Google laptops, phones, and speakers in the U.S. </p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">The allegations </h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Sonos showed Google its blueprints in 2013 under a partnership to integrate Google’s music service with its speakers. Three years later, Google released a wireless competitor, the Google Home.</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Suspicious, Sonos sniffed around and concluded Google used its tech. It explained this to Google several times between 2016–2019 and asked that Google at least license it. </span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>Sonos says Amazon </span><span><a href="https://www.theverge.com/2020/1/7/21055048/sonos-google-lawsuit-sues-speakers-assistant-amazon?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">also infringed</a></span><span> on its patents in Echo devices, but...one schoolyard fight at a time.</span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">The defense:</strong> A Google spokesman said the company's “disappointed” Sonos is pursuing a lawsuit and that all claims are false. </p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">We’ve heard this song before</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">With roughly 1,500 employees and $1+ billion in annual speaker sales, Sonos isn’t a mom and pop shop. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">But that doesn’t mean it’s playing on a level field, writes the NYT: “As the biggest tech companies have become essential to reach customers and build businesses, they have exploited that leverage over smaller companies to steal their ideas and their customers.”</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Sonos, like many other companies, uses Google’s ad platform and Amazon’s retail and cloud services. </span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Google and Amazon can also subsidize products through other business units to undercut rivals (their Home and Echo devices can run $50, while Sonos speakers start at $180). Google sells nearly as many speakers in a quarter as Sonos does in a year. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Big picture: </strong>This suit reinforces complaints that Google and Amazon squeeze oxygen out of competition. Both are already facing <a href="https://www.cnbc.com/2019/11/14/states-google-antitrust-probe-to-expand-into-search-android-businesses.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">antitrust probes</a>, and Sonos execs have reportedly discussed testifying to a House committee.</p>

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
INVESTING
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/01/07/robinhood-clear-leader-among-investment-apps-analysis-shows?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
The Future (of Investing Apps) Is Now
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<!--[if mso]>
<img alt="Robinhood men in tights " style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" height=363 src="https://media.giphy.com/media/rkXNems5uxExG/giphy.gif">
<![endif]-->
<!--[if !mso]>--><!-- -->
<img class="story-header-image" alt="Robinhood men in tights " style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" src="https://media.giphy.com/media/rkXNems5uxExG/giphy.gif">
<!--<![endif]-->
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Giphy</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Since Thiel & Co. got together to crack the online payment nut in 1998 (PayPal), fintech has surfed from personal finance (Mint) to point-of-sale (Square) to payment processing (Stripe). </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Another fintech frontier:</strong> Investment platforms, where insurgents are pushing incumbents off the dance floor. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Want more detail? This week, the good people of Apptopia <a href="https://blog.apptopia.com/robinhood-now-has-more-mobile-monthly-active-users-than-the-top-legacy-providers-combined?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">analyzed</a> the investment app landscape. Here’s what they found: </p>
<ol>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Robinhood’s the clear leader. The app has more mobile monthly active users than the top legacy players (E-Trade, TD Ameritrade, Edward Jones, and Fidelity) combined. </span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Quarterly downloads of the top investment-based finance apps (Robinhood, Acorns, Stash, Betterment, and others) have collectively grown 126% from Q4 2015 through Q3 2019. </span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>The gender breakdown is...uneven. Men account for no less than 69% of total active users at each of the major investment apps. Acorns has the highest proportion of female users (30.4%), while E-Trade ranks last at 15.8%. </span></li>
</ol>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Bottom line: </strong>Robinhood’s no-fee trading has already forced legacy brokerages to eliminate commissions. This report indicates they’d be wise to follow the new kid’s focus on mobile as well.</p>

</span><span><strong style="color:#000">What got into Elon Musk in Shanghai?</strong></span><span> He made it through a presentation yesterday without shattering any windows. Plus, Tesla delivered its first China-made Model 3s to the public and said its new Model Y compact SUV would be produced in Shanghai. "Ultimately the Model Y will have more demand than probably all of the other cars of Tesla combined," </span><span><a href="https://www.cnn.com/2020/01/07/tech/tesla-elon-musk-china/index.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Musk said</a></span><span>. </span>

<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>After it unveiled the (</span><span><a href="https://www.cnet.com/news/ps5-instead-unveiling-new-playstation-5-console-sony-showed-this-logo/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">uninspired</a></span><span>) logo for the PlayStation 5, Sony </span><span><a href="https://www.theverge.com/2020/1/6/21054270/sony-vision-s-electric-concept-car-ev-announcement-ces-2020?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">surprised CES</a></span><span> by revealing a concept electric sedan, the Vision-S. </span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>Also at CES, Toyota </span><span><a href="https://www.reuters.com/article/us-tech-ces-toyota/toyota-to-build-prototype-city-of-the-future-in-japan-idUSKBN1Z5271?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">announced plans</a></span><span> to build a “city of the future” at the base of Mt. </li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>Far away from CES, GM reported that sales in China </span><span><a href="https://www.cnbc.com/2020/01/07/gm-warns-of-ongoing-challenges-in-china-as-sales-fall-15percent-in-2019.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">dipped 15.1%</a></span><span> in 2019, its second straight year of declines in the world’s largest auto market. </span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>In the British luxury sector, Rolls-Royce rolled to its </span><span><a href="https://www.reuters.com/article/us-britain-autos-rolls-royce/carmaker-rolls-royce-annual-sales-surge-25-idUSKBN1Z60FJ?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">best year ever</a></span><span> with sales up 25%. </span><span><a href="https://www.cnn.com/2020/01/07/investing/aston-martin/index.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Aston Martin</a></span><span>, however, warned its 2019 profit would drop by ~45%.</span>

<img alt="Risk board " style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiIxNTc4NDA2MjA1LmpwZyIsImJ1Y2tldCI6Im1vcm5pbmdicmV3LW9zbG8iLCJlZGl0cyI6eyJyZXNpemUiOnsid2lkdGgiOjEwMDAsImhlaWdodCI6bnVsbH19fQ==">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Francis Scialabba</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">On the list of things that keep investors up at night, geopolitical risks are up there with “Did I leave the garage door open?” </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Political risk consulting firm Eurasia Group has released its <a href="https://www.eurasiagroup.net/issues/top-risks-2020?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">top risks of 2020</a>. If you’re the type to worry, here’s some ammo...</p>
<ol>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>
</span><span><strong style="color:#000">U.S. politics. </strong></span><span>“We face risks of a U.S. election that many will view as illegitimate, uncertainty in its aftermath, and a foreign policy environment made less stable by the resulting vacuum.”</span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span><strong style="color:#000">The tech “decoupling” of the U.S. and China. </strong></span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span><strong style="color:#000">General U.S./China tensions.</strong></span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>
</span><span><strong style="color:#000">Multinational corporations face backlash. </strong></span><span><span>“Nation-states are reasserting themselves, presenting new risks to the capital and assets of corporations.”</span></span><span>
</span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span><strong style="color:#000">Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s controversial agenda.</strong></span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span><strong style="color:#000">A more aggressive, independent Europe.</strong></span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>
</span><span><strong style="color:#000">The politics vs. economics of climate change. </strong></span><span><span>The failure of climate policy will lead to “suboptimal corporate decision-making, operational business disruptions, and political instability.”</span></span><span>
</span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span><strong style="color:#000">Failed U.S. policy in Shia-led nations in the Middle East. </strong></span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span><strong style="color:#000">Discontent in Latin America.</strong></span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span><strong style="color:#000">Turkey’s flailing economy and government.</strong></span></li>
</ol>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">What did they miss? </p>

Scialabba\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eListening to music on a Sonos speaker is like getting a personal serenade from Nick Jonas. But after going on tour with Big Tech, the high-end speaker company wants out: Yesterday, Sonos \u003ca href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/07/technology/sonos-sues-google.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003esued\u003c/a\u003e Google for allegedly infringing on five of its patents, the NYT reports. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eIn a \u003ca href=\"https://www.scribd.com/document/442039322/Sonos-ITC-Complaint-against-Google?campaign=SkimbitLtd\u0026ad_group=66960X1514734Xe44b477fa03a05e24af3574ac830e523\u0026keyword=660149026\u0026source=hp_affiliate\u0026medium=affiliate\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eseparate case\u003c/a\u003e, it's also requesting a ban on the sale of Google laptops, phones, and speakers in the U.S. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eThe allegations \u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eSonos showed Google its blueprints in 2013 under a partnership to integrate Google’s music service with its speakers. Three years later, Google released a wireless competitor, the Google Home.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eSuspicious, Sonos sniffed around and concluded Google used its tech. It explained this to Google several times between 2016–2019 and asked that Google at least license it. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eSonos says Amazon \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.theverge.com/2020/1/7/21055048/sonos-google-lawsuit-sues-speakers-assistant-amazon?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ealso infringed\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e on its patents in Echo devices, but...one schoolyard fight at a time.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eThe defense:\u003c/strong\u003e A Google spokesman said the company's “disappointed” Sonos is pursuing a lawsuit and that all claims are false. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eWe’ve heard this song before\u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eWith roughly 1,500 employees and $1+ billion in annual speaker sales, Sonos isn’t a mom and pop shop. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eBut that doesn’t mean it’s playing on a level field, writes the NYT: “As the biggest tech companies have become essential to reach customers and build businesses, they have exploited that leverage over smaller companies to steal their ideas and their customers.”\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eSonos, like many other companies, uses Google’s ad platform and Amazon’s retail and cloud services. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eGoogle and Amazon can also subsidize products through other business units to undercut rivals (their Home and Echo devices can run $50, while Sonos speakers start at $180). Google sells nearly as many speakers in a quarter as Sonos does in a year. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBig picture: \u003c/strong\u003eThis suit reinforces complaints that Google and Amazon squeeze oxygen out of competition. Both are already facing \u003ca href=\"https://www.cnbc.com/2019/11/14/states-google-antitrust-probe-to-expand-into-search-android-businesses.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eantitrust probes\u003c/a\u003e, and Sonos execs have reportedly discussed testifying to a House committee.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eSince Thiel \u0026 Co. got together to crack the online payment nut in 1998 (PayPal), fintech has surfed from personal finance (Mint) to point-of-sale (Square) to payment processing (Stripe). \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eAnother fintech frontier:\u003c/strong\u003e Investment platforms, where insurgents are pushing incumbents off the dance floor. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eWant more detail? This week, the good people of Apptopia \u003ca href=\"https://blog.apptopia.com/robinhood-now-has-more-mobile-monthly-active-users-than-the-top-legacy-providers-combined?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eanalyzed\u003c/a\u003e the investment app landscape. Here’s what they found: \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003col\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eRobinhood’s the clear leader. The app has more mobile monthly active users than the top legacy players (E-Trade, TD Ameritrade, Edward Jones, and Fidelity) combined. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eQuarterly downloads of the top investment-based finance apps (Robinhood, Acorns, Stash, Betterment, and others) have collectively grown 126% from Q4 2015 through Q3 2019. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eThe gender breakdown is...uneven. Men account for no less than 69% of total active users at each of the major investment apps. Acorns has the highest proportion of female users (30.4%), while E-Trade ranks last at 15.8%. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ol\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBottom line: \u003c/strong\u003eRobinhood’s no-fee trading has already forced legacy brokerages to eliminate commissions. This report indicates they’d be wise to follow the new kid’s focus on mobile as well.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003e\n\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eWhat got into Elon Musk in
